David,

In this particular case your technique would work.

I wonder, when =
testing return values that are slightly more complicated, if
this would sta=
rt to fall apart. I don't have specific examples I can give
you just yet.

=
I will give this some more thought, and maybe try some code. Before I went
=
very far I wanted to make sure there wasn't an existing system I should use=
.

Thanks for the responses. I have listened to the JUnit group for a while=
,
but this was my first post.

Landon (AKA The Sunburned Surveyor)



On Fr=
i, Nov 20, 2009 at 11:22 AM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:

>
>
> Dear=
 Sunburned,
>
> If I write
>
> assertEquals("(1,-1,0)", point.toString());
=
>
> and change the toString method, I get this (slightly garbled, but
> mos=
tly helpful) failure:
>
> org.junit.ComparisonFailure: expected:<[(1,-1,0)]=
> but was:<[[1, -1, 0]]>
> at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:123=
)...
>
> This seems to cover the one example you cite. Are there others?
>
=
> David Saff
>
>
> On Fri, Nov 20, 2009 at 1:06 PM, Sunburned Surveyor
> <s=
unburned.surveyor@... <sunburned.surveyor%40gmail.com>> wrote:
> > I =
have a question about the options for gathering and displaying
> > suppleme=
ntal information about test failures. Please allow me to
> > illustrate my =
question with a simple example.
> >
> > I've got a class called Coordinate =
that represents a point in a 3D
> > coordinate system. I've overloaded the =
toString method of this class
> > to write out the X, Y, and Z values of th=
e coordinate in a simple
> > String. Now I want to test my toString method =
using JUnit.
> >
> > If the Coordinate.toString test method fails (because =
the string was
> > not constructed in the correct format) I would like to p=
rovide the
> > programmer running the test with a copy of the incorrect str=
ing, since
> > it provides valuable clues about what is broken with the met=
hod under
> > test. I typically do this by placing System.err.println state=
ments in
> > my test method. However, I realize that using System.err.print=
ln isn't
> > the most portable or elegant way to provide this information t=
o the
> > programmer executing the test.
> >
> > What I really want is a GU=
I that allows the programmer to select a
> > failed test from a list of fai=
led tests, and then to view supplemental
> > test data I provide him/her.
>=
 >
> > I was thinking I could do this by completing the following tasks:
> =
>
> > - Implementing the RunListener interface in JUnit.
> > - Create an ex=
tension of Exception that could contain a HashMap of
> > simple parameters =
and that would be passed to the constructor of a
> > Failure object from wi=
thin a test.
> > - Creating Failure objects in my tests that contain the su=
pplemental
> > failrure data.
> > - Passing these failure objects to my Run=
Listener implementaiton.
> > - Creating a FailureProcessor class that displ=
ays a GUI with the
> > information in my RunListener implemenation to show =
the programmer
> > executing my tests the supplemental failure data as desc=
ribed above.
> > (FailureProcessor would be an interface so that you could =
do different
> > things with the supplemental failure data, not just show i=
t in a GUI.)
> >
> > Before I begin this work, I wanted to ask if there was=
 a better way to
> > do this. I know I could use a logging framework from w=
ithin my test
> > method, but I really want to work within the JUnut framew=
ork, not
> > outside of it. I also want a nice little GUI, not a log file.
=
> >
> > How are other programmers handling instances when they want to disp=
lay
> > supplemental data on failed tests? Does my approach sound reasonabl=
e?
> >
> > The Sunburned Surveyor
> >
